response.answer_text: The photon sphere(s) of a black hole are unstable, so the net amount of light that might end up there is (almost certainly) not enough to self-react. If there's an accretion disk you might get all kinds of Compton scattering (with matter), and Hawking radiation is something weird with light. Wheeler suggested a circular ball of light so intense that its energy curved space time into a 'lens' that kept it confined in the middle. In this case, light is self-interacting, as it can also do in intense bursts of gamma rays.  In matter light can also interact with itself via 3 or 4 wave mixing, but that's not really relevant to your question!

No, light only travels in straight lines (according to the local geography). It is not attracted by anything, especially other photons. But when considering a black hole, yes. The momentum in photons absorbed by the black hole adds to the mass, thanks to energy-mass equivalence. Not sure what you mean by a black hole "re-collapsing". But no, the mass outside of a black hole cannot draw out the matter that has been lost to the singularity. All mass or energy outside the black hole can do is enlarge the black hole.

Light certainly does attract light. Light has energy, so it generates a gravitational field. It is even speculated that a black hole could be formed by light alone (and this is entirely consistent with GR), see for example Kugelblitz (astrophysics)
